events.text: J.C.R. Licklider of MIT envisions a globally interconnected set of computers through which everyone could quickly access data and programs from any site.
Leonard Kleinrock, Thomas Merrill and Lawrence G. Roberts connected two computers: The TX-2 in Massachusetts to the Q-32 in California. Creating the first wide-area computer link.
MIT (1961-1967), RAND (1962-1965) & NPL (1964-1967) all independently proceeded on works about packet switching networks at the same time.
ARPA awards contracts for the development of ARPANET, directed by Robert Taylor and Lawrence G. Roberts, adopting packet switching technology.
A network of Interface Message Processors designed by Bob Kahn and built by Bolt, Beranek and Newman is created. An early version of a router.
Several packet-switched networks emerge such as the NPL network in the UK and the CYCLADES in France.
Ray Tomlinson sends the first mail message between two computers on the ARPANET, introducing the '@' address syntax designating the user's system address.
Initiatives start to develop the internetwork, in which separate networks could be joined into a network of networks.
The first public packing switch networks such as the RETD in Spain, and the RCP network in France based on the X.25 protocol designed by Rémi Després.
Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn develop the TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and Internet Protocol (IP) in the Internet protocol suite.
Developed by John Vittal, the first modern email program was developed that allowed for the function to reply and forward emails.
The first BBS (Bulletin Board System) was developed by Ward Christensen and Randy Suess during a blizzard.
USENET is created to host news and discussions.
ARPANET computers switch over to TCP/IP and the Domain Name System (DNS) is established with familiar .com, .net and .edu naming system for websites.
IRC or Internet Relay Chat was first developed, being the first real-time chat and instant messaging service.
Commercial entities start emerging to provide internet, called internet service providers (ISPs)
Tim Berners-Lee proposes the World Wide Web, originally called Mesh that links hypertext documents to an information system, accessible from any node to the network.
The first web page is created.
Mosaic, developed by Marc Andreeset and Eric Bina at NCSA was created. Mosaic was the first widely downloaded internet browser.
Netscape Navigator the first dominant web browser in terms of usage share was created.
The internet becomes commercialized following the first internet transactions. SSL, a transport layer security protocl was released to authenticate and encrypt messages.
HoTMaiL, the first webmail service launches.
A team at CSIRO invents the Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) that allowed devices to connect to a network through radio waves.
Google
the dotcom bubble collapses, resulting in huge losses for investors.
Wikipedia launches it's collective web content distribution that is maintained by a communitiy of volunteers.
VoIP (Voice over IP) service Skype is released to the public, giving a user-friendly service for individuals to contact others through the internetwork.
Web 2.0, referring to highly interactive and user-driven websites becomes popular. At this time, Facebook launches.
Youtube launches, bringing online video hosting avaliable to the public for free.
Twitter launches, allowing users to air out their thoughts to the public for free.
The iPhone releases, leading towards interest in mobile web applications and responsive content.
The first cryptocurrency Bitcoin launches as open source software.
ICANN, the official naming body of the internet, who manages domain name regulation relaxes their control.
The first commercial transaction using Bitcoin is made for two Papa John's pizzas.
Adobe Creative Cloud is launched, introducing a subscription service to their applications.
Iconic video 'Gangnam style' released by PSY is put on Youtube.
Internet banking becomes mainstream, allowing users to easily manage their funds.
The FCC rules in favour in net neutrality to keep the internet open and free for everyone.
TikTok, a hub for sharing video content releases.
5G, a cellular network technology releases as a successor to 4G networks.
The shift towards remote working due to a pandemic results in increased internet usage.
NFTs
ChatGPT launches, allowing for a publicly available artificial intelligence that allows for people to generate text, images and gather information and more.
